title: Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma in a Young Patient
setup_script: “A 25-year-old man with a family history of MEN 2 presents for evaluation of a thyroid nodule. His serum calcitonin is elevated. Genetic testing confirms a RET mutation. Ultrasound shows a 1.8 cm hypoechoic thyroid nodule without suspicious cervical lymphadenopathy. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about associated endocrinopathies
dynamic_flow.reply: Provide that plasma metanephrines are normal and calcium/PTH are normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds without pheochromocytoma workup
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops severe intraoperative hypertension during induction of anesthesia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests neck ultrasound findings
dynamic_flow.reply: Provide that there is a 1.8 cm hypoechoic thyroid nodule, no pathologic cervical lymphadenopathy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about calcitonin level

dynamic_flow.reply: Ask what procedure they would recommend for this patient.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends thyroid lobectomy only
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops recurrent disease on follow-up calcitonin testing and imaging.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends total thyroidectomy without central neck dissection
dynamic_flow.reply: Pathology shows multiple positive central lymph nodes not removed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection
dynamic_flow.reply: Pathology confirms medullary thyroid carcinoma, with 2 of 8 central lymph nodes positive.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about lateral neck management
dynamic_flow.reply: No suspicious lymph nodes are seen on imaging; intraoperatively, no gross lateral disease is found.
Pathology reveals medullary thyroid carcinoma, 1.8 cm, margins negative, 2 of 8 central lymph nodes positive, no extrathyroidal extension.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative monitoring
dynamic_flow.reply: Post-op calcium is normal, vocal cord function intact. Calcitonin on POD 1 is undetectable.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about long-term follow-up
dynamic_flow.reply: Recommend serial calcitonin and CEA levels every 6 months, annual neck ultrasound.
Patient is referred for genetic counseling; his younger sister is also found to carry a RET mutation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address family screening
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner asks what recommendations they have for at-risk family members.
Prognosis depends on early intervention and calcitonin doubling time; currently favorable given complete resection and undetectable postoperative calcitonin.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of MEN 2 and importance of evaluating for pheochromocytoma prior to thyroid surgery.
Decision regarding appropriate surgical procedure (total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection).
Understanding that radioiodine ablation is not indicated for medullary thyroid carcinoma.
Genetic counseling and family screening for RET mutation.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the hereditary nature of medullary thyroid carcinoma and incorporating MEN 2 evaluation. You communicated your surgical plan clearly and showed good understanding of the operative and postoperative considerations.Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition of the importance of pheochromocytoma screening would improve patient safety. Consider strengthening your approach to nodal management in medullary thyroid carcinoma and expanding discussion of long-term genetic counseling implications.Suggested Reading Topics: - SCORE Curriculum: Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma - ACS/ASE Review Manual: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Syndromes - ATA Guidelines on Management of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma
